entry.title: R Notes(III)
entry.content: Basic skills of plotIn this artical, I will use the data “mtcars” in the R language itself to draw many kinds of pictures. So let’s have a preliminary understand of R plot. You can see the concreate code here.I will give you a brief introduction of the function plot. plotYou can use function plot to get the first and the last figures above, which you just need to modify parameters to get. Usage: plot(x,y,…) Arguements: x,y are the datas you need to input.“…” means the other parameters you need to modify.For some examples, “main=title” means an overall title for the plot. “sub” means a subtitle for the plot. xlab means a title for x axis. You can see more parameters with the word help(“plot”) in R. So let’s see a concreate example.attach(mtcars) opar<-par(no.readonly=TRUE) par(lty=2,pch=2) plot(head(wt),head(mpg),type="b",main="wt-mpg") par(opar) detach(mtcars) I put the codes in the pages below the figure, and I will explain the codes lines and lines. The first and last lines mean attach the data “mtcars” and detach the data. The second line is to generate a list of current graphical parameters that can be modified, which means you must use it. And the third line, of course, is to modify the parameters. Lty is the abbreviation of the type of line. Lty=2 means the dotted line. Pch=17 is the point character, which means the solid triangle. The following pictures show the usage of parameters. Of course, the parameters is more than just pch and lty, such as lwd, cex and so on. The lwd means the width of line and the cex means the size of symbol. You can refer to the help docement for more specific information. what’s more, the R also can modify the axis by yourself. You can clearly see the figure above and the code is here. By the code, we can know the line axis(4,at=x,labels = x,col.axis="blue",las=2,cex.axis=0.7,) that controls the output of axis. The parameter in the code is shown below. 4 stands for the position. 1 is the bottle. 2 is the left side. 3 is the up side. 4 is the right side. at means the scale of the axis. las=2 means the word is perpendicular to the axis and las=0 means the word is parallel to the axis.If you want to know more about the parameter of the axis, you can refer to the document of help.

entry.title: Gradient Descent Method(I)
entry.content: Gradient Descent Method(I)Basic InformationThe gradient descent method is an optimization algorithm, also known as steepest descent. The steepest descent method is one of the simplest and oldest methods for solving unconstrained optimization problems. Solving ProcessThe calculation of the gradient descent method is to solve the minimum value in the direction of the gradient descent (and also to solve the maximum value along the ascending direction of the gradient).$a_(k+1)=a_k+\rho_k*s_. s_k$represents the gradient negative direction, while the \rho_k stands for the search step in the gradient direction.Gradient direction, we can get the derivative of the function, the step size is more difficult to determine, too big, it may be divergent, too small, convergence is too slow.The general method of determining the step size is determined by the linear search algorithm, which treats the coordinates of the next point as a function of a_k, and then satisfies the minimum of F(a_k+1).Because under normal circumstances, the gradient vector is 0 words that is to an extreme point, the gradient amplitude is 0 and the gradient descent algorithm for optimization, the termination condition is the amplitude of the gradient vector iteration algorithm is close to 0, you can set a constant threshold is very small. entry.title: Kmeans
entry.content: Kmeans AlgorithmBasic InformationK-means is a typical clustering algorithm based on distance, using the distance as a similarity evaluation index. The closer between two objects, the greater similarity is. It is considered that the clusters are made up of objects which are close to each other, so the compact and independent clusters are chosen as the final target. The selection of K initial cluster centers has a great influence on the clustering results, because the first step of the algorithm is to select any k objects randomly as the center of the initial clustering, and represent a cluster. In each iteration of the algorithm, each object remaining in the data set is re assigned to the nearest cluster based on the distance from each cluster center. When all data objects are examined, an iterative operation is completed, and a new cluster center is calculated. If the value of J does not change before and after an iteration, the algorithm is proved to be convergent. Algorithm ProcessInput: The numbers of clusters k, and the database containing N data objects. Ouput: K clustering with minimum variance criterion. (1) K objects are selected as initial cluster centers from N data objects. (2) According to the mean (central object) of each cluster, calculate the distances between each object and the central object. And also, on the basis of minimum distance, the corresponding objects are divided. (3) Recalculate the value of each (with change) clustering (center object). (4) Cycle (2) to (3) until each cluster does not change. Algorithm Advantages The algorithm is simple. It is efficient and scalable for large data sets. Algiruthm Disadvantages In the K-means algorithm K is given in advance, the selection of this K value is very difficult to estimate. In the K-means algorithm, it is necessary to determine an initial partition according to the initial cluster center, and then optimize the initial partition. The selection of the initial cluster center has a great impact on the clustering results. Once the initial value is not good, it may not be able to get effective clustering results, which has become a major problem of the K-means algorithm. From the framework of K-means algorithm can be seen, the algorithm needs to constantly adjust constantly calculating the sample classification, a new clustering center adjusted, so when there is a very large amount of data, the algorithm time overhead is very large. entry.title: PSO Algorithm
entry.content: PSO AlgorithmQuote The PSO algorithm is an evolutionary computation, which is propsoed by Dr.Eberhart and Dr.Kennedy. This algorithm is originally based on the study of bird predation behaviour, inspired by the rules of birds cluster and then build a simplified model by using swarm intelligence. And now, PSO algorithm is based on the observation of animal cluster activity, making use of the information sharing among the individuals in the group which makes the motion of the whole group evolve from disorder to order in the problem solving space, so that you can get theoptimum solution. Algorithm Inrtoduction As mentioned earlier, PSO simulated predation behavior of birds. Imagine a scenario: a flock of birds in the random search of food. There is only one piece of food in this area. All the birds don’t know where the food is. But they know how far away the food is. So what is the best strategy to find food?. The simplest and most effective way is to search the area around the nearest bird. PSO is used to solve the optimization problem. In PSO, the solution of each optimization problem is a bird in the search space. We call it a particle. All particles have an adaptive value determined by the optimized function, and each particle has a velocity that determines the direction and distance of their flight. Then the particles follow the optimal particle in the solution space. PSO is initialized to a group of random particles. And then find the optimal solution by iteration. In each iteration, the particle updates itself by tracking two “extremes”. The first one is the optimal solution of the particle itself, which is called the pBest. The other extreme is the optimal solution which is found in the whole population. The extreme value is the global extreme value gBest. In addition, it is possible to use only a part of the neighborhood as a particle without the whole population. When finding these two optimal values, the particle updates its speed and new position according to the following formula: $V=\omega *V+C1*rand()*(pbest-present) +C2*rand()*(gbest-present)$ $present=present+V$ In the formulas above, V is the particle velocity. C1 and C2 are learning factors. \omega is a weighting factor. The rand() is random number between zero and one. Parameter Setting The number of particle generally take 20 to 40. In fact, 10 particles can get good results. Particle length: This is determined by the optimization problem, is the length of the problem solution. The scope of the particle: by the optimization problem, each dimension can be set different range. The learning factors usually take 2, also depending on the specific situation. Break condition: Maximum number of cycles and minimum error requirements. Matlab CodeYou can get code here.
